newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish brewer Brok says Holsten to up stake.
newsitem.headline: Polish brewer Brok says Holsten to up stake.

text.p: Polish brewer Brok said on Tuesday Germany's Holsten brewer planned to raise to a majority the stake it held in the group, and it would enter the Warsaw bourse in 1997's first half after a public offering.
"We'll be on the bourse's (now vacant) third market because for the time being we don't fulfil the qualifications to be on the main or parallel floors," spokeswoman Agnieska Pluszcz told Reuters.
Shareholders will vote on September 23 on whether Zaklady Piwowarskie Brok SA -- will conduct a one-to-five share split and issue 575,000 new shares to AHK Beteiligungsgesellschaft.
AHK is jointly owned by Holsten and another German investor, AMS of Hamburg.

Brok, which currently has 230,000 shares, would then issue another 287,500 shares in a public offering likely in the second quarter of 1997, after which AHK's stake would rise to 51 percent from the current 40 percent.
Management would hold 33 percent, individual investors 17 percent, Bank Pekao SA nine percent and the state treasury one percent.

Funds from the AHK share issue would go toward modernising one of Brok's three breweries in northwestern Poland, with funds from the second issue buying a new brewing plant at the company's headquarters in Koszalin.
Brok plans to invest 90 million zlotys over the next three years, more than doubling production from the current 550,000 hectolitres annually.
The brewer now has a three-percent market share.
